intro.p: Speaking of web-accessibility, the visually impaired have the most painpoints. According to the EBU more than 4% of the european population is blind or partially sighted. They use screen reader. A screen reader is a tool that reads content aloud. There are different types of screen readers, the most popular Screen Readers are JAWS and Zoom Text:

img.alt: Chart of primary screen reader usage showing decreases in JAWS, NVDA, VoiceOver, SA and significant increases in ZoomText and Window-Eyes.
img.caption: Chart based on Data from webaim.org a textual description can be found there.

ul: All concepts introduced on this page were tested with VoiceOver and JAWS in June 2016.

paragraphs.li: Screen reader can read text, and interpret special attributes written in HTML, most modern screen reader can also list common items as all headers, links, forms and tables.
The usual painpoints are a bad page strukture, images, svg, graphs, videos, forms, tables, repetitive elements, visual features, popups.
Screen readers have no problems using javascript.
Almost all screen reader obey display:none and visibility:hidden by ignoring the element.
To have elements visually hidden but still accessible for screen readers the W3C suggests this css method:
Of course you can also do the contrary. Hide text for screen readers but show it visually by using aria-hidden="true". The support for aria-hidden is brilliant.

writings.screenReader: When you build a website or a webapp, you want it to be successfull. Right?
You want everyone to use it. Right?
Then, why would you leave out eleven percent of the population?

writings.screenReader: Imagine increasing sales by eleven percent, while doing good. Neat right?
Open up your websites for the physically impaired. Make them accessible!
It is not difficult, nor will it cost a fortune. You have no excuse.
Accessibility is like opening your door to everyone.
